page.title: Quantifiers and QP - No other modifiers
page.introduction:
The second set includes quantifiers like some, every, and no, which do not allow any other articles, demonstratives or possessors in the nominal phrase.
Beginning again with the positive quantifiers, English examples (1-2) show what is grammatical, but examples (3-5) illustrate that these words do no co-occur with articles, demonstratives or possessors. Note that an example like some of the children is grammatical, but this is a case of some as the head of the nominal phrase, with a partitive phrase of the children modifying it, which will be covered in
Pronouns - Pronouns as a Nominal Phrase

EnglishExample.exItem: almost every litle girl that I see

page.introduction: Because they take the place of articles, demonstratives and possessors, we will treat these quantifiers as determiners which stand alone with their own phrase structure rule.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have positive quantifiers like ‘some’ and ‘every’ which are written as separate words and act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, ‘some’ and ‘every’ are written as separate words and act in this manner
Some are written as separate words and act in this manner, but some attach to another word in the nominal phrase
No, the meanings of both ‘some’ and ‘every’ are not expressed by separate words but instead by clitics or affixes that attach to another word in the nominal phrase

No, ‘some’ and ‘every’ either act like the special degree elements on the previous page or may instead be quantifiers that may co-occur with articles, demonstratives and/or possessors to be treated on the next page

form.prompt: For those elements meaning ‘some’ or ‘every’ which attach to another word, please return to the previous page and include them as clitics or affixes there.
Make sure that you include the words meaning some and every on either the previous page or the next page as appropriate.

radioGroup.prompt: You said that your language has classifiers which mark concord agreement throughout the nominal phrases. Do these quantifier determiners which act as the only modifier within the nominal phrase have classifiers attached to them?
radioGroup.radio: No, these elements are not marked with classifiers
Yes, these elements are marked with classifiers as part of the concord agreement throughout the nominal phrase

form.introduction: Now consider the negative quantifier determiner meaning ‘no’. We are looking for examples such as (1-2). Note that ‘no’ contrasts with ‘not’ from the previous page in that ‘no’ cannot occur with articles, demonstratives or possessors, as (3-5) demonstrate.

radioGroup.prompt: Think about how similar examples to (1-2) would be expressed in your language. Does your language have one or more negative quantifiers meaning ‘no’ which are written as separate words and act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
Some are written as separate words and act in this manner, but some attach to another word in the nominal phrase
No, the meaning of ‘no’ is not expressed by a separate word but instead by a clitic or affix that attaches to another word in the nominal phrase
No, ‘no’ is the same as the negative special degree element ‘not’ on the previous page
No, just as there is not any way to express the negative special degree element ‘not’ on the previous page, there is not any way to express ‘no’ modifying a nominal phrase in this language

form.prompt: For those elements meaning ‘no’ which attach to another word, please return to the previous page and include them as clitics or affixes there. You may need to change your answers on that page.
Make sure that the element meaning no was fully dealt with on the previous page.

If it is incorrect that your language does not have any way of negating a nominal phrase, change your answer on this page if the negative element is a separate word that cannot co-occur with articles, demonstratives, or possessors. If the negative element is a clitic or an affix, or if it is a separate word which can co-occur with articles, demonstratives, or possessors, go back to the previous page and change your answers there before returning to this page. If your language truly does not have any way of negating a nominal phrase, proceed to the next page.

form.instruction: In the lexicon, mark this type of quantifier determiner that is written as a separate word with the feature makeDet. This will change their category to Det for the syntax. If a particular quantifier determiner can only go with plural nouns or if it marks plural itself (such as some), add the feature plural to that entry. If a particular quantifier determiner can only go with singular nouns (such as every in English), add the feature singular to that entry. Do not add either feature to a quantifier determiner which can go with either singular or plural nouns.

In the lexicon, mark this type of quantifier determiner that is written as a separate word with the features makeDet negative. This will change their category to Det for the syntax, as well as marking it as negative.

Those which can only occur before the noun also need to have the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur after the noun also need the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature DP-initial or DP-final on any quantifier determiners which can occur on either side of the noun.

Those which can only occur before the noun also need to have the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur after the noun also need the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature DP-initial or DP-final on any negative quantifier determiners which can occur on either side of the noun.
